item.title: Ukraine Commander Says Russia Shows No Sign of Winding Down War
item.description: Russia shows no signs it plans to wind down its war in Ukraine, with an estimated 695,000 troops deployed across an expanded front line and another 121,000 in strategic reserve, according to Ukraine’s commander-in-chief Oleksandr Syrskyi.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: Oleksandr Syrskyi.

item.title: Gulf States Fear Escalation as US Iran Strikes Rattle Region
item.description: Iran’s Arab neighbors urged restraint and warned of potentially devastating implications for the region after US strikes on Tehran’s nuclear program raised the prospects for all-out war in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Peter Martin, Fiona MacDonald

media:content.media:description: Abbas Araghchi, speaks during a press conference at the Lutfi Krdar Congress Center on the sideline of the 51st session of the Council of Foreign Ministers of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC), in Istanbul on June 22,

item.title: UK Says It’s Not Involved in US Strikes on Iran, Urges Talks
item.description: The UK and its military assets weren’t involved in US strikes on Iran’s main nuclear sites and is calling for a diplomatic solution to the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer Photographer: Jordan Pettitt/EMPPL PA Wire

item.title: US Attacks Nuclear Sites in Iran, Widening Mideast Conflict
item.description: American bombers struck Iran’s three main nuclear sites overnight, putting the US directly into Tehran’s war with Israel despite President Donald Trump’s longtime promises to avoid new conflicts.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Akayla Gardner, Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: President Trump walks from Marine One after arriving on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, DC, on June 21.

item.title: Australia Urges De-Escalation After US Hits Iran’s Nuclear Sites
item.description: Australia’s government called for de-escalation, dialog and diplomacy after the US struck Iran’s three main nuclear sites and threatened more attacks.
item.dc:creator: Malcolm Scott

media:content.media:description: RAMALLAH, WEST BANK - JUNE 22: Missiles fired from Iran in retaliation for Israeli attacks are seen in the sky over the Ramallah, West Bank on June 22, 2025. (Photo by Issam Rimawi/Anadolu via Getty Images)

item.title: Europe Frets About US Retreating From Region Ahead of NATO
item.description: NATO’s European allies are focused on getting through this week’s summit unscathed. But even if President Donald Trump is satisfied with fresh pledges to ramp up spending, anxiety is growing about the US military presence in the region.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano, Michael Nienaber, Natalia Drozdiak

media:content.media:description: Boris Pistorius and Friedrich Merz unveil a new battle tank brigade in Lithuania. Photographer: Michael Kappeler/dpa/AP Photo

item.title: Malaysia Says US Agrees to Finalize Trade Talks Before Deadline
item.description: Malaysia and the US have agreed to finalize trade negotiations before the tariff reprieve expires, the Malaysia’s Ministry of Investment, Trade and Industry said.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

item.title: US Strikes on Iran Come at Fragile Moment for the Global Economy
item.description: US strikes on Iran’s three main nuclear facilities come at a fragile moment for the global economy, and the outlook now hinges on how forcefully the Islamic Republic retaliates.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan, Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Photo by ATTA KENARE/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: ATTA KENARE/AFP

item.title: Iran Says US Attacks on Three Nuclear Sites Were ‘Savage’
item.description: Iran’s warned that US strikes on three Iranian nuclear sites early Sunday will trigger “everlasting consequences” and said it “reserves all options” to respond.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: The Isfahan enrichment facility on June 3. Source: Satellite image (c) 2025 Maxar Technologies

item.title: Farage’s Rise Calls Bank of England Independence Into Question
item.description: In the nearly three decades since Gordon Brown handed control of interest rates to the Bank of England, the move has been broadly viewed as a success in helping to keep inflation under control. Now that consensus appears to be breaking down.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Nigel Farage Photographer: Jason C. Andrew/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel Awakes to a New Reality After US Strikes Iranian Sites
item.description: Israelis woke up to a new reality Sunday after President Donald Trump confirmed that the US bombed Iran’s three main nuclear sites, diminishing a threat they’ve considered existential for decades.
item.dc:creator: Ethan Bronner

media:content.media:description: A rescue worker evacuates two children from the site where a missile launched from Iran struck Haifa, Israel on June 22. Photographer: Baz Ratner/AP Photo

item.title: Thailand, Cambodia Shut Land Crossings in Escalating Border Spat
item.description: Thailand and Cambodia shut several border crossings in tit-for-tat moves, ratcheting up tensions between the two Southeast Asian neighbors as Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra fights to save her government from a political crisis triggered by a leaked phone call over the weekslong standoff.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Photo by Sovannara/Xinhua via Getty Images) Photographer: Xinhua News Agency/Xinhua News Agency

item.title: Trump Makes Dramatic About-Face With Plunge Into Middle East War
item.description: President Donald Trump has long advocated for keeping the US out of Middle Eastern wars. By joining Israel’s offensive against Iran, he is making a dramatic geopolitical u-turn.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, left, and Marco Rubio, US secretary of state, during an address to the nation in the East Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, June 21, 2025. Trump said the US military struck three sites in Iran on Saturday, marking the first American involvement in direct attacks against Iranian nuclear assets in its conflict with Israel.

item.title: Trump Pressures Iran to Make Peace, Threatening More US Strikes
item.description: US President Donald Trump said in an address to the nation that US strikes had “completely and totally obliterated” Iran’s three main nuclear facilities, and threatened further military action if Tehran did not make peace with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Jennifer A Dlouhy, Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump speaks in the East Room of the White House on June 21. Photographer: Bloomberg/Bloomberg Economics

item.title: Australia Says It Will Base Defense Spending on Country’s Needs
item.description: Australia’s deputy prime minister said the nation will base defense spending on national interest, amid calls by President Donald Trump for US Indo-Pacific allies to increase military budgets.
item.dc:creator: Malcolm Scott

media:content.media:description: Richard Marles Photographer: Ore Huiying/Bloomberg

item.title: Iran Reserves All Options After US Hits Nuclear Sites

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump speaks in the East Room of the White House on June 21. Photographer: Bloomberg/Bloomberg Economics

item.title: UK to Invest £275 Million to Train Skilled British Workers
item.description: The UK will invest £275 million ($371 million) to grow the country’s skilled workforce as Prime Minister Keir Starmer seeks to accelerate economic growth and reduce reliance on foreign labor.
item.dc:creator: Tofe Ayeni

media:content.media:description: Workers on the HS2 High-Speed railway construction site at Old Oak Common in London, UK, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. Costs attached to the rail project, which was originally designed to link London to Manchester and Leeds, via Birmingham, had risen to as much as 98 billion ($128 billion) by 2020, up from an initial estimate of 37.5 billion for the entire network.

item.title: Trump’s ‘Two Weeks’ Pause on Iran Strikes Comes With High Stakes
item.description: President Donald Trump often suggests that something will happen in “two weeks” when he’s looking to buy himself some time. But his latest two-weeks declaration — on possible US military strikes in Iran — comes with unusually high stakes.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Onur Ant

media:content.media:description: Damage to a building hit by a ballistic missile launched from Iran in Bat Yam, Israel, on Sunday, June 15, 2025. Israel and Iran continued intense bombardments on one another’s territories for the third day, with no sign of a reprieve and growing concerns over a wider conflict in one of the world’s key oil-producing regions. Photographer: Kobi Wolf/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel-Iran Trade Fresh Blows as US Bombers Fly Over Pacific
item.description: Israel and Iran launched new strikes in a second week of hostilities, with the Isfahan nuclear facility targeted again, as Donald Trump deepened uncertainty about his readiness to join the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Abeer Abu Omar, Eltaf Najafizada, Sara Gharaibeh, Ethan Bronner

item.title: Trump Envoy’s Belarus Visit Is Followed by Prisoner Release
item.description: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko released 14 imprisoned opposition activists after meeting with a US presidential envoy in the highest-level contact between the two countries in years.
item.dc:creator: Aliaksandr Kudrytski

media:content.media:description: Alexander Lukashenko Photographer: Alexander KAZAKOV/AFP

item.title: B-2 Bombers Have Departed the US as Trump Weighs Iran Strike
item.description: B-2 stealth bombers have taken off from the US and are headed over the Pacific, multiple news outlets reported, as President Donald Trump weighs American involvement in the war between Israel and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Tony Czuczka

media:content.media:description: A B-2 bomber is refueled at Whiteman Air Force Base, Missouri, on May 28, 2025.

item.title: Yemen’s Houthis Threaten to Hit US Ships If Trump Attacks Iran
item.description: Yemen’s Houthis said they will target US vessels and battleships in the Red Sea if the the Trump administration gets involved to support the Israeli attack on Iran, according to a statement published on a Houthi spokesperson’s official Telegram account.
item.dc:creator: Sara Gharaibeh

media:content.media:description: Houthi supporters surround an Iranian flag during an anti-US and anti-Israel rally in Sanaa, Yemen, on June 20, 2025.

item.title: Romania Heads for Broad Ruling Coalition After Months of Turmoil
item.description: Romania is heading toward a broad coalition government to tackle the European Union’s biggest budget shortfall after the largest pro-European party voted to join the cabinet of Prime Minister-designate Ilie Bolojan.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Nicusor Dan and designated Prime Minister Ilie Bolojan (R) shake hands a joint press statement at Cotroceni Palace, the Romanian Presidency's headquarters, in Bucharest June 20,

item.title: EU Frets Over US Demands in Trade Talks It Sees as Unbalanced
item.description: The US is demanding the European Union make what the bloc’s officials see as unbalanced, unilateral concessions as part of ongoing trade talks, setting up a tough decision over whether to move ahead with countermeasures if the terms of any deal don’t improve.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

item.title: Ukraine Amasses $43 Billion for Defense Industry, Zelenskiy Says
item.description: Ukraine has accumulated $43 billion for its defence industry so far this year between local funding and aid from allies, using it to ramp up the production and purchase of drones, artillery and other weaponry, said President Volodymyr Zelenskiy.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova, Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: UKrainian Vampire hexacopter bomber drones at the Skyfall military technology company at an unknown location in Ukraine, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. Ukraine is developing a new generation of drones that target incoming unmanned aerial vehicles, as Kyiv seeks to reduce its reliance on US-made Patriot missile systems for air defense.

item.title: India Won’t Restore Water-Sharing Pact With Pakistan, Shah Says
item.description: India’s home minister has ruled out restoring a water-sharing pact with Pakistan, according to the Times of India newspaper, signaling a rapprochement was out of the question despite the neighbors reaching a military truce.
item.dc:creator: Subhadip Sircar

media:content.media:description: Mountains are reflected in water flowing through the Nubra Valley, where the Nubra river flows into the Shyok river as part of the Indus River system, that separates the Ladakh and Karakaoram ranges in Nubra, Jamma and Kashmir, India, on Thursday, Nov. 14, 2019. There is a body of evidence that global warming is disturbing water cycles on the roof of the world, and in unpredictable ways. Snow cover is shrinking, glaciers are melting, the monsoon season changing and permafrost is at risk, all with drastic consequences for a region whose ice fields hold the largest freshwater reserves outside the poles.

item.title: Thai Premier Won’t Quit to Save Government, Ruling Party Says
item.description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra will not resign or dissolve parliament, her party said Saturday, amid reports the leader may step down to keep the ruling coalition in power and to end a political crisis triggered by comments she had made that were critical of the army.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra, Thailand's prime minister, during a news conference in Bangkok, Thailand, on Thursday, June 19, 2025. Thailand's government faces collapse after a leaked phone call unleashed fresh political turmoil, with Paetongtarn facing resignation calls and street protests as she grapples with the exit of the second-biggest party in her coalition.

item.title: Pakistan Backs Trump for Nobel Peace Prize He’s Long Craved
item.description: Pakistan said it will nominate US President Donald Trump for the Nobel Peace Prize, a move that may annoy rival India while building stronger ties to Washington.
item.dc:creator: Subhadip Sircar

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump at the White House on June 09, 2025 in Washington, DC.

item.title: Starmer Faces Brewing Rebellion Over £5 Billion Benefit Cut
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is less than 10 days away from the biggest parliamentary challenge to his authority in his not-yet year-long tenure.
item.dc:creator: Ailbhe Rea, Lucy White, Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s Top HK Official Says Security Will Ensure City’s Success
item.description: China’s top official for Hong Kong affairs said the city needs to prioritize national security to ensure prosperity.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Kwan

media:content.media:description: Xia Baolong Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg
